2. Search for rows where the "constellation" column is "leo". This will help us identify all NGC objects that belong to Leo constellation.

3. Count the number of these rows to find out how many objects are in the Leo constellation according to the table.

4. Check if any of the NGC objects in the Leo constellation have a "constellation" column value other than "leo". This will help us ensure that all identified objects truly belong to Leo constellation as per the table.

5. Compare the number of Leo constellation objects found against the total count of objects to see if there are any objects in Leo constellation that do not match its name (i.e., have a different constellation value).

6. If there is no object with a "constellation" value other than "leo", then check if exactly one object has a "constellation" value of "chamaeleon". This will help us verify the claim that only NGC 3195 belongs to Chamaeleon constellation.

7. If there is no object with a "constellation" value other than "leo", and exactly one object has a "constellation" value of "chamaeleon," then the claim is TRUE: There are multiple NGC objects in Leo, but only NGC 3195 belongs to Chamaeleon.

8. If there is an object with a "constellation" value other than "leo", or if more than one object has a "constellation" value of "chamaeleon," then the claim is FALSE.
